headline.main: Hard to Pronounce, Infinitely Harder to Cure

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses lymphangioleiomyomatosis, rare lung disease commonly known as LAM; disease generally occurs in women of childbearing age; 350,000 women worldwide are believed to have LAM, but because it is so rare there is little support for finding cure; life expectancy of those who have disease ranges up to 20 years; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In the ''life is not fair'' department, Amy Farber and several hundred other women like her have been dealt a particularly nasty blow. They have a disease that few people, including doctors, have ever heard of -- a very rare, progressive and ultimately fatal lung disease that primarily affects young women. Its cause is unknown, and there is no effective treatment. Furthermore, the name of the disease is hardly memorable: lymphangioleiomyomatosis, (pronounced lim-FAN-zhee-oh-LYE-oh-MY-oh-muh-TOE-sis), or LAM for short.
